NOTICE:
MISS AULD

Memo to inform the ladies of Prince Albert and vicinity that the ladies have opened out of business effective October 1st. Miss Auld, Francis Williams, and McCullough.
We are now prepared to give our attention to the sale of Ladies' Fashion goods, Hosiery, Millinery, Fancy Gowns, and other goods.
We will open at our new location at the Prince Albert, pr. E. St. Louis, E. St. Louis.
We would respectfully request that everyone connected with the trade to cooperate and assist in our effort to keep Prince Albert in fashion.
Miss Auld & Co.

Profit Sale.
Selling everything in stock at low prices.
We have a large and well-stocked stock of Millinery and Fancy Goods.
Having received the services of a First-class Dress & Manteau Maker.
In the past, we have been able to execute all orders promptly as far as the latest fashion.
Our goods are noted for their fashionable shape and superior quality.

Miss Auld & Co.

November 9th, 1893.

Report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Death of Mrs. McPherson.
COURT AT BATTLEFORD
Plateau Road, Prince Albert.
The Court opened Tuesday morning at 10 o'clock.
The police have been requested to assist in the investigation.
Weather fine, but cold wind and rainy weather.

NECROLOGY
MISS AULD

Miss Auld, of Prince Albert, passed away recently after a short illness.
She was an active member of the local women's club.
Her death is regretted by her friends and family.

THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW.
TERRITORIAL NEWS

RIGGINA.

From the Leader, Oct. 25.

Mr. Caron, of the Public Works Department, has been removed to Calgary. Mr. Caron and family went to Calgary last week.

The M. L. A.'s have this morning met at Moose House for a Christmas dinner. Hon. David Ross, Capt. Henry Mitchell and Richardson, Mr. James McLeod is also here.

A meeting of the Royal Order of Canada was held in Prince Albert today. The chair was occupied by President Mountz. Hon. Norman was present and Mr. B. E. Bradwell, Trustee, the first meeting being held on Thanksgiving Day, November 26th. Hon. Norman was chosen chairman and Mr. Bradwell Vice-Chairman. All appointments and everything possible is being done to make the day a success.

BATTLEFORD.

From the Herald, Oct. 26.

A second violent act of Sandy Wood's mischief last week before it was shot.

Some weeks ago Mr. Schiller's workshop between Saturday night and Monday morning and removed a pair of windows which badly glinted.

The Rev. J. J. Taylor, Mrs. Taylor and family returned from Prince Albert on route to Oskar Lake. They took the journey at Battleford, stopping at the home of Mr. Morris. Mr. Taylor takes charge of the Cerebral Missionary Society's station at Oskar Lake.

As a result of a few dissensions among the farmers of the district, at the close of the agricultural society meeting on Monday, Mr. F. G. Bradwell, the chairman, made a statement that it costs 40 cents per loaded to make oats for market, and will do so as long as the present circumstances of the country continue.

FORT MACLEOD.

From the Globe, Oct. 25.

The Cochran Bandos Club conducted a dinner and dance during the present season. Some from this remote fetched £15 6s per head in England.

Last night will long be remembered as one of the most memorable nights of Macleod. Mr. Harry Taylor, a public spirited citizen may own night feel proud of possessing such a large number of people from all parts of the district in a banquet, which he gave in honor of Mr. F. G. Bradwell, M. L. A. The banquet was attended by Mr. Bradwell, who is nearly surrounded by larger affairs of a similar nature in the east. Mr. Bradwell is in the midst of a campaign, dealing mainly with the liquor question and the question of self-government. Among those present at the dinner were Mr. Wilson who was the only member supporting the license system. He assured three present that Dr. Wilson would find a strong supporter in him.

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin, Oct. 20.

Reported to be a policeman riding in Edmonton from Athabasca on Friday night, but has since been heard to say a bush alongside the road by some person concealed there. He was not struck.

According to latest reports, the party accompanying the horseman, who it is said were two white men, who broke off with him, and a Blackfoot Indian. The rider was seen to be searched and the white men have been brought off from George having him alone.

On Monday night D. S. McKay, living about two miles west of the town on the road to Edmonton, was killed by a bullet amongst his feet, while going to investigate a house a man going away with one or more of his horses. He was killed for making the third time he refused to stop. He was sent west in the police car to Edmonton west next. Following the occurrence there by the train they came upon the remains of a horse which he had started the chickens. The ashes were still warm when the police arrived but Keeseeawans had gone on.

QUAPPULIE.

From the Palliser, Oct. 30.

The Rev. Alex. Macquillan and family, of Prince Albert, arrived in town today, the names of their former telegraph office to other places of habitation.

On the evening of yesterday R. W. Roy, Wm. H. Bell, G. S. W., G. L. M., and W. Roy, H. B. Van Erp, of Winnipeg, visited the Quappulie Valley Lodge, A.F. & A.M., for the purpose of conferring and instructing the brethren in masonry. The visiting brethren first delivered the instructions to the members of the lodge, translated them by means of a stenographer, after which R. W. Roy Bell delivered a discourse on the subject of Freemasonry. At the close of the meeting the brethren were entertained at suppers by the lodge, the guests dining at the Indian Head, where they delivered their return before the Indian Head Lodge.

About six inches of snow fell on Well Head last night in very soft and melting away.

Wheat is selling now from $1 to $2 10. Barley is selling from 20 cents per pound. Eggs 20 cents per dozen. Potatoes are also sold at from 20 cents to 25 cents per barrel. Oats are selling at from 20 to 25 cents per barrel. Barley 30 cents to 40 cents.

SILK RIBBONS.

Those of our lady readers who would like to have an elegant, large package of extra fine, assorted Ribbons (by mail) directed to us, will find them a valuable addition; adapted for Bonnet Strings, Neckwear, Scarfs, Trimming for Ladies' Hats, etc. We pay Postage, and can get any article we desire, according to the recent failure of a large number of orders. We are now addressing only 25 cents to the address we receive.

As a special offer, this house will give away any order for any other item in American type will send any order to P.O. address of the newly married ladies in this paper. No prices less than one dollar will be charged. Orders will be filled promptly. Children in need of clothes will be sent 10 cents each. We will send any order to P.O. address of the newly married ladies in this paper. No prices less than one dollar will be charged. Orders will be filled promptly.

AGENTS:

P. G. GRAY,

Edmonton, Alta.

J. FRASER TIMS,

Fort Saskatchewan Alt.

Mahaffey & Clinkskill,

Battleford, Sask.
TOWN COUNCIL.

On Monday evening last Coun. McPhail, Mr. Pierson, Knowles, Davis, Appelton, and Johnson assembled at the Civic Board to have their usual weekly meeting.

His Worship the Mayor not being present Coun. Knowles moved to elect Mr. Pierson in his place to occupy the chair. Carried.

COMMITTEES.

A communication was read from W. Maclean, Almshouse Trustee, asking Mr. Pierson to take charge of the E. C. School District, asking for $350. From Mr. Maclean's request for a drug store, Mr. Pierson replied that he could not agree.

A by-law to regulate the storage of gunpowder etc., and to be signed by him No. 8 was introduced.

Coun. Johnson, chairman of the Board of Works, presented the report of that committee, which recommended the payment of several accounts amounting to nearly $600.

The Fire, Water and Light Committee recommended the payment of the following accounts: Mr. D. Murray, $25; Mr. Dunlop, $25 50; Mr. Moffat, $25 07. The same committee recommended that the report as agreed to be referred to the arbitrator for settlement.

The council went into

COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE.

To consider the report of the Fire, Water and Light Committee. Coun. Stewart in the chair. At 10 o'clock the committee rose, but no motion being put they decided to meet another hour.

Up to this hour a lot of useless discussion had been going on, and even though the operative were under the impression that they were allowed to add to the fire ward, the council had threatened a couple of times to send them away.

Coun. Stewart moved and Coun. John seconded: That the Fire, Water and Light Committee be instructed to report the next meeting of the council whether so far that the task before them is referred to the solicitor. The motion was lost, it only getting the support of Coun. Davis, Stovesh and McKeown.

Some more valuable time was again consumed in a lot of useless chatter, but the council decided to break up, although they would get through the work.

Coun. McPhail moved and Coun. John seconded: That the Fire, Water and Light Committee be instructed to report the next meeting of the council whether so far that the task before them is referred to the solicitor. The motion was lost, it only getting the support of Coun. Davis, Stovesh and McKeown.

In amendment Coun. Davis moved and seconded: That the Board of Works be instructed to erect the new water main and sewers on King Street from River Street to Ferry Street. But the above motion and amendment were rejected.

A motion by Coun. Agnew seconded by Coun. Stewart: That the council pay over the balance of the money between the two dry stores, that the same be paid out of the general fund and that the balance of the Board be instructed to do the work, was carried.

Coun. Agnew moved and Coun. Davis seconded: That the Board of Works put down the new water main on River Street as ordered by the last meeting of the council. Carried.

A by-law to be signed by No. 8, for the prevention of fire and accidents, was put through its various stages and ordered to be engrossed.

Coun. Agnew moved and Coun. Davis seconded: That the letter from W. T. Maclean be referred to the solicitor.

Coun. Agnew moved and Coun. Davis seconded: That the report of the Fire, Water and Light Committee be adopted except the item re tank which is to be referred to the solicitor, also the report of the Firemen's and Mechanics' reports be embodied in the minutes of the Committee. Carried.

There being no more important business to be done and as the clock had just struck one, the council adjourned.

Going to the newspapers and a widespread circulation of forged bills of the bank of British North America, it has decided to withdraw all bills of that denomination from this circulation.

MEDICINE HAT.

From the Times, Oct. 25.

Considerable rain fell on Tuesday.

The Saskatchewan River is very low.

F. Hodgson, commandant of the work camp, of which Mr. Hodgson is in charge, has disappeared.

Mr. Pierry, of Fort Saskatchewan, was on his way east yesterday morning to Toronto. Mr. Pierry will enjoy a vacation of several weeks, and on his return will be able to report on the progress made.

Crowfoot, chief of the Blackfoot Indians, accompanied by three minor chiefs, left Medicine Hat yesterday morning for the boundary line. It is understood that his mission is to meet the Gros Ventres Indians, for the purpose of making peace between the two nations.

CALGARY.

From the Tribune, Oct. 24.

Mr. Markley, president of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company, arrived in town with his wife Wednesday, and will take up his residence here.

Mr. Justice Bowden delivered judgment in the case on the appeal court of the Northwest Land Surveyors on the decision of the Court of Revision on the assessment of 1887.
